presentSimple.iYouWeThey: present simple I / you / we / they have

definitions.definition: to own, hold or possess something

examples.text: He had a new car and a boat.
Have you got a job yet?
I don't have that much money on me.
She's got a BA in English.

definitions.definition: be made up of

examples.text: In 2023 the party had 10 000 members.

definitions.definition: to show a quality or feature

examples.text: The ham had a smoky flavour.
The house has gas-fired central heating.
The car has four-wheel drive.
They have a lot of courage.
He's got a front tooth missing.

definitions.definition: to show a particular quality by your actions

examples.text: Surely she didn't have the nerve to say that to him?

definitions.definition: used to show a particular relationship

examples.text: He's got three children.
Do you have a client named Peters?

definitions.definition: to be able to make use of something because it is available

examples.text: Have you got time to call him?
We have no choice in the matter.

definitions.definition: to be in a position where you ought to do something

examples.text: We have a duty to care for the refugees.

definitions.definition: to be in a position of needing to do something

examples.text: I've got a lot of homework tonight.
I must go—I have a bus to catch.

definitions.definition: to let a feeling or thought come into your mind

examples.text: He had the strong impression that someone was watching him.
We've got a few ideas for the title.
**I've got it!** We'll call it ‘Word Magic’.

definitions.definition: to suffer from an illness or a disease

examples.text: I've got a headache.
He found out that he had HIV just last year.
I had a cold yesterday and I couldn't come to work.

definitions.definition: to hold somebody/something in the way mentioned

examples.text: She'd got him by the collar.
He had his head in his hands.

definitions.definition: to place or keep something in a particular position

examples.text: Mary had her back to me.
I soon had the fish in a net.

definitions.definition: to experience something

examples.text: I went to a few parties and had a good time.
I was having difficulty in staying awake.
She'll have an accident one day.

definitions.definition: to organize or hold an event

examples.text: Let's have a party.

definitions.definition: to eat, drink or smoke something

examples.text: to **have breakfast/lunch/dinner**
I'll have the salmon *(= for example, in a restaurant)*.
I had a coffee while I was waiting.
Have you had breakfast yet?
I just had a sandwich for lunch.
He went outside to have a cigarette.

definitions.definition: to perform a particular action

examples.text: I had a swim to cool down.
to **have a wash/shower/bath**
We had a very interesting discussion about climate change.

definitions.definition: to give birth to somebody/something

examples.text: She's going to have a baby.
Our cat has just had five kittens.

definitions.definition: to produce a particular effect

examples.text: His paintings had a strong influence on me as a student.
The colour green has a restful effect.

definitions.definition: to receive something from somebody

examples.text: I had a letter from my brother this morning.
**Can I have** a Coke, please?

definitions.definition: to be given something; to have something done to you

examples.text: I'm having treatment for my back problem.
How many driving lessons have you had so far?

definitions.definition: to experience the effects of somebody’s actions

examples.text: We have orders coming in from all over the world.

definitions.definition: to suffer the effects of what somebody else does to you

examples.text: She had her bag stolen.

definitions.definition: to cause something to be done for you by somebody else

examples.text: You've had your hair cut!
We're having our car repaired.

definitions.definition: to tell or arrange for somebody to do something for you
definitions.sensetop: have somebody do somethinghave somebody + adv./prep.

examples.text: He had the bouncers throw them out of the club.
**I'll have you know** *(= I'm telling you)* I'm a black belt in judo.
She's always having the builders in to do something or other.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to be in a particular state; to make somebody react in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: have somebody/something + adj.have somebody/something doing something

examples.text: I want to have everything ready in good time.
He had his audience listening attentively.

definitions.definition: to be with somebody

examples.text: She had some friends with her.

definitions.definition: to take care of somebody/something in your home, especially for a limited period

examples.text: We're having the kids for the weekend.

definitions.definition: to entertain somebody in your home

examples.text: We had some friends to dinner last night.

definitions.definition: to allow something; to accept something without complaining

examples.text: I'm sick of your rudeness—I won't have it any longer!
We can't have people arriving late all the time.

definitions.definition: to put somebody at a disadvantage in an argument

examples.text: **You've got me there**. I hadn't thought of that.

definitions.definition: to have sex with somebody

examples.text: He had her in his office.

definitions.definition: to trick or cheat somebody

examples.text: I'm afraid you've been had.

definitions.definition: to take or accept somebody for a particular role

examples.text: Who can we have as treasurer?

definitions.definition: to dislike somebody because of something bad they have done to you in the past

examples.text: I don’t have anything against her, we just don’t get along.

definitions.definition: to finish something unpleasant so that it does not continue

examples.text: Let's have done with this silly argument.

definitions.definition: to be in a very bad condition; to be unable to be repaired

examples.text: The car had had it.

definitions.definition: to be extremely tired

examples.text: I've had it! I'm going to bed.

definitions.definition: to have lost all chance of surviving something

examples.text: When the truck smashed into me, I thought I'd had it.

definitions.definition: to be going to experience something unpleasant

examples.text: Dad saw you scratch the car—you've had it now!

definitions.definition: to be unable to accept a situation any longer

examples.text: **I’ve had it (up to here) with him**—he’s done it once too often.

definitions.definition: to claim that it is a fact that…

examples.text: **Rumour has it** that we'll have a new manager soon.

definitions.definition: to be likely to suffer the unpleasant effects of your actions and to deserve to do so

examples.text: It was no surprise when she left him—everyone knew he had it coming to him.

definitions.definition: to not like somebody and be unpleasant to them
to be capable of doing something

examples.text: Everyone thinks he has it in him to produce a literary classic.
You were great. I didn't know you had it in you.
You spoke really well at that meeting, standing up for us all. I never knew you had it in you.

definitions.definition: to have sex with somebody
to be not nearly as good as somebody/something
not willing to listen to or believe something

examples.text: I tried to persuade her to wait but she wasn't having any.

definitions.definition: other things, people, etc. of the same kind

examples.text: There's room in the cellar to store old furniture and what have you.

wordOrigin: Old English habban, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hebben and German haben, also probably to heave.
